BE

2015 net debt target of US$25bn in-line with our estimate although
GLEN includes streaming agreements. Earnings power in Marketing
confirmed at US$2.5-2.6bn for 2015. Few surprises in 3Q industrial
production. Key risk still earnings sensitivity to commodity prices
and Fx in Industrials. Stay EW.

11:10 am
BE

So, yes.

BE

Stay EW: The key focus is on GLEN's ability to reduce net debt to at least
US$21-22bn by end 2016, maintain the long term earnings power of
Marketing at US$2.7bn and generate positive FCF in the Industrial assets. The
3Q report shows the group is on its way to hitting its debt objectives including
some benefit from the streaming agreements in 2015 already (Silver Wheaton
deal of US$0.9bn). The earnings power for Marketing has been confirmed for
2015 as well. Lower RMIs at year-end will keep the discussion open over the
long term outlook for Marketing until the update call on 10 December. The key
risk remains the sensitivity in the earnings of the Industrial assets to 10%
moves in commodity prices offset by an equal move in FX, which is around
US$1.0-1.1bn of EBITDA, on an annual basis. This impact is challenging to deal
with on an already financially levered Industrial business.

BE

The group
targets US$40bn of net funding and US$25bn of net debt by the end of 2015
(US$29.6bn in 1H15). In addition to the unchanged objective of net debt in low
twenties by end 2016. The 2015 net debt objective is exactly in line with our
forecasts (on spot). However, the group includes the US$0.9bn inflow from the
Antamina streaming deal with Silver Wheaton in that target whereas we do
not. That means the inflow of working capital (ex Readily Marketable
Inventories) is likely to be less than the US$4.4bn we estimate for 2015
(US$3.3bn in 1H15) or cash generation in Industrials is lower than we forecast.
Liquidity of US$13.8bn at end of September (US$10.5bn 30 June) was used to
repay US$1.95bn in bonds and buy back US$0.4bn of bonds post that date.

11:11 am
BE

With
eight weeks to go, and some of the November profits already locked in, the
group reiterated it US$2.5-2.6 billion EBIT target for 2015 (MSe US$2.46bn)
That implies an annualised EBIT of US$2.9-3.1bn in 2H15 using on average
Readily Marketable Inventories (RMI) of around US$16bn for 2H. Guidance on
profit objectives beyond 2016 will most likely be provided on 10 Dec. The key
question remains if the earnings power of physical commodity traders in
general (not just Glencore) can be maintained post the super cycle with both
asset turnover and profit per trade under debate. Exhibit 2 shows that
Glencore has hit its US$2.7-3.7bn EBIT target range (up from US$2.0-3.0bn post the acquisition of Xstrata in May 2013) nearly three times in the last 4 half
year periods (2H15 included). It managed to do that with RMI's averaging
between US$16.0-18.5 during the period. At end 2015 the group expects RMI's
of US$15.0. It is therefore not impossible Marketing profits will get close to the
long term guidance range based on recent performance, in our view.

BE

BMO also. Agreeing that it's good news but nothing unexpected.

BE

Our View:
 Positive. The company can use the cash towards achieving its net debt target of the low US$20Bs (including Readily Marketable Inventories) by year-end 2016. Further, Glencore is in discussions regarding additional streams and asset sales.
BMO Research already assumes US$2B in asset sales in its estimates, with net debt forecast at US$19.5B by year-end 2016.
 BMO Research estimates the deal to be ~1% NPV accretive to Glencore, valuing the stream at ~US$400-500M using a 10% discount rate. BMO Research notes that the US$900M paid for Glencore's 33.75% silver stream is broadly in line with the US$610M received by Teck Resources (TCK.B; C$8.09, Market Perform, covered by Sasha Bukacheva, BMO Nesbitt Burns Inc.) for its 22.5% silver stream from Antamina announced recently.
 From a production standpoint, the quarterly result and revised guidance were broadly in line with expectations, and therefore are not expected to make a significant impact to earnings estimates.

PM

Bermuda Triangle 2 – into uncharted waters

BE

Go on.

PM

Will throw up the cover sheet

11:15 am
PM

As highlighted in our previous report, Bermuda Triangle – The shrinking
slice of equity pie (28 September), it is increasingly challenging to value
mining equities as commodity prices plunge and abnormally high levels of
debt distort valuations. The mining industry is effectively in uncharted
waters. Symptomatic of extreme nervousness is the emergence of a “price
discovery zone” where markets attempt to establish the value remaining for
equity holders. In extreme cases, effectively all that may be left for current
shareholders is option value on a recovery in commodity prices.

PM

Debt has become the major focus for investors in mining companies as the
sector has woken up to the consequences of high levels of gearing, when
combined with a severe slump in commodity prices. The fact that sector M&A
and the capacity expansions of recent years were funded almost solely through
cheap (at the time) debt has left many mining companies in uncharted waters.
 When commodity prices fall, the equity value of companies with high levels of
debt becomes increasingly difficult to determine, as the market struggles to
identify appropriate valuation methods. Symptomatic of this period is what we
term a “price discovery zone” (PDZ), characterised by a dramatic increase in
price volatility and volume of shares traded – essentially when the company’s
Enterprise Value (EV) is increasingly dominated by debt. Empirically, it appears
to be triggered when market cap falls below the level of net debt.

PM

This report examines the four UK-listed major diversified miners and shows that
the Glencore (recently downgraded to Sell, from Hold) and Anglo American
(Hold) share prices are already exhibiting the characteristics of a PDZ. We note
other internationally traded companies in the mining sector also demonstrate
such symptoms. In our view, investors are being forced to evaluate such
companies using short-term metrics, essentially to ascertain if they will survive in
their present form long enough for commodity prices to recover.
 We do not suggest that highly indebted mining companies will become insolvent,
but we do see situations where the value to current equity holders falls close to
zero as such companies are forced to switch their focus to servicing debt as the
cost of raising new equity becomes disproportionately high. Existing equity may
thus come to represent little more than an option on commodity price recovery

11:15 am
PM

As a result, investors are currently focussed on valuations based on prevailing
spot prices. Our central case remains for a slow recovery in commodity prices
starting from mid-2016, but this view is predicated on conditions in China not
worsening further. We believe we are still a distance away from a “value point” in
the sector. We therefore think that the market is likely to remain fixated with
valuations based on ‘spot’, especially for companies with high debt loadings, and
that volatility in commodity prices will continue to be magnified in share price
moves.

PM

11:19 am
BE

BE

Here's the top line of the Goodbody note, by the way, though I reiterate it's from yesterday.

BE

Merger with Coral is a positive move
The combined entity of Ladbrokes and Coral looks set to generate £500m EBITDA
in FY18. There are a number of positives to the deal including: (i) significant
synergies; (ii) strengthening of the management team; (iii) increased online
exposure; (iv) omni-channel capabilities; and (v) potential to improve risk
management.
Less than 400 shop divestments could be necessary
This deal was blocked in 1998. However, market dynamics, competitive forces and
product mix have since changed significantly. The focus is likely to be on local level
competition and our detailed analysis shows the divestment of less than 400 shops
could appease concerns.
Ladbrokes standalone valuation offers support
While we still believe Ladbrokes has significant work to do to turnaround its
business, the Q3 performance showed some early positive signals. Our standalone
valuation for Ladbrokes of 115p gives comfort if the deal does not proceed.
Risk reward appears attractive - upgrade to BUY
We believe there are good prospects for the deal getting approved. The significant
synergy potential can drive upside to EBITDA. While the enlarged group will be far
from a leader in online, its exposure to this channel will increase from currently
low levels which can drive a re-rating. We believe a PT of 145p is achievable (this
attaches an equal weighting to our standalone and merger valuations). As this is
38% above the current price, we upgrade to BUY from HOLD.

BE

What we can say is that forecasts are coming back.

BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

We are reducing our estimates today to reflect the dual impact of elections &
investment. Without the help of Help to Buy equity loans, the existing homes
transaction market has not been as sheltered as the new-build sector from the
impact of May's general election. Transaction levels were muted ahead of the
election and have not picked up afterwards as we anticipated. Investment: the
seeds (costs) have been planted, but the fruits will take time to develop

11:24 am
BE

Elections: The latest land registry data shows that housing transactions are down 8% in
the year to July 2015 and we have not seen the post-election pick-up we have seen across
the last seven election years. Countrywide's volumes are down 10% year to date, on the
face a loss of market share, but in the detail a protection of fee rates and cash fees, a sensible
strategy in our view.
Growth: Countrywide has made its intentions clear: to double EBITDA by 2020, from
£121m in FY2014 to £242m in FY2020. A fall in profits in year one adds to the challenge,
although some of that decline is due to the investment which will help deliver that growth.
While we are downgrading our estimates today, there has been no rebasing or dumbing
down of the aspirations or strategic intent to double the profits of the business by 2020.
Dividends: In CY15 total ordinary DPS will be maintained at the CY14 level of 15p. Going
forward, the guidance is for 35%-45% of underlying PBT with aspirations to reintroduce
special dividends in CY17.

BE

Estimate changes: Overall we are downgrading our EBITDA estimates as follows: CY2015E
-11%; CY2016E -7% and CY2017E -6%. Our housing transaction assumptions assume a 5%
fall in CY2015 (previously we had assumed a 2.5% fall) and we expect CWD's transactions to
fall by 9% (previously 6%) as they protect fee levels. We continue to expect 3% transaction
growth in CY2016 and CY2017 albeit from a lower base. Investment in growth reflects more
than half of the near-term estimate changes.

Property developers are facing a big increase in the fees they are charged for making planning applications as part of the government’s attempts to balance the books in the autumn spending review.
The proposals are part of an attempt by ministers to shift spending from the state to “consumers” — whether companies, individuals or students. Other examples include a switch in student maintenance allowances to loans, a planned change in innovation grants to loans and a mooted increase in visa charges.

BE

Anyway, returning to Countrywide, Goldman sees it as a profit warning so I will too.

11:28 am
BE

News
Countrywide (Neutral) has issued a profit warning today based on a slower
pace of recovery seen in housing market volumes in 2H15. The company
notes that group EBITDA in 9M15 is down 11% yoy and therefore
anticipates FY15 EBITDA to below the £121 mn achieved in FY14. We note
current Reuters consensus of £125 mn implies 3% growth yoy (GSe: 2%). In
terms of outlook, the company notes that the current economic backdrop
and improving consumer confidence point to modest transaction growth in
2016 (GSe: +4%). The company notes that the group’s medium 5-year
targets will require an increased level of investment, but expects to
maintain the dividend payout of 35%-45% of underlying profit after tax with
a view of paying special dividends from 2017 onwards.
Analysis
As noted in our 3Q preview, recent data has shown a divergent trend
between the newbuild and secondary market. We note that Countrywide’s
estate agency segment has seen houses exchanged down 12% YTD, and
management now expects the overall market to decline by at least 5% (GS
FY15: -2%). The London agency segment has been more resilient, with
volumes tracking +2% YTD. The lettings segment remains fairly resilient as
well, with properties under management growing by 5% in 3Q15 and up
7% YTD (GS FY: 9%). The company remains committed to investing in the
lettings business in anticipation of future growth and in order to increase
the resilience to the sales cycle volatility.
Implications
We expect a negative reaction to the shares. We note that Countrywide
shares are down 8%/10% over the last 1m/3m and currently trade on
8.6x/7.3x CY16/17 EV/EBITDA (on our unchanged estimates).

One who is wandering will be in a conversation with a group, but then with no hesitation will be (sometimes seen) in another group of random people either causing a comedic scene or escalating situation. Those who engage in mandering try to never cause harm, but just aimlessly walk into scenarios in a leisure manner with no fear of any consequences that may arise. They may get lost and not recollect where they had dissapeared off especially under a high level of intoxication.

BE

Q2 GM like for like down 1.9%. Misses consensus by a full percentage point.

BE

But gross margin improves 285bps and we get an upgrade to guidance.

BE

All in all, unexpected. The possibility that M&S has pricing power outside food hasn't really been considered as a theme.

11:35 am
BE

Let me cut to Barclays.

BE

We believe that given M&S is treated as a margin improvement story by investors, what will matter more on balance today will be the strong GM gross margin beat and the bulls will be happy to see the story is intact with raised FY guidance and a very decent H1 PBT beat. The continuous market share losses in clothing though could cast some doubt about the sustainability of the company’s restructuring story longer term, while weaker Food gross margin may hold back the shares from reacting too strongly on the back of a good H1.

BE

And RBC, which has been pushing for a while.

11:36 am
BE

M&S has reported better than expected HY results with PBT of £284mn versus our high end £279mn estimate and consensus of £270mn, driven by
a stronger UK gross margin performance, with underlying EPS of 14.1p compared to our 13.9p forecast. Q2 clothing LFL and international profits
were softer than expected. Dividend per share of 6.8p is in line with our estimate. M&S has raised its guidance for UK gross margin for the year
from +150-200bps to up +200-250bps, maintained its opex guidance of +4% which looks conservative to us and lowered its tax rate guidance for
the year from 20% to 17.5%. We think consensus PBT forecasts will hold but EPS forecasts should move up at least 3% due to the lower tax rate
guidance. There is an analysts’ meeting at 9am to discuss the results in more detail.
UK Retail EBIT including Financial Services was £306mn compared to our £289mn estimate. International EBIT was £25mn compared to our £36mn forecast,
mainly owing to a softer than expected franchisee performance by Fiba Retail in Russia/Turkey/Ukraine and a weaker Euro trend versus sterling.
Outstanding General Merchandise (GM) gross margin, food margin slightly weaker. In H1 M&S’ General Merchandise gross margin rose by +285bps
yoy compared to our +210bps yoy estimate, mainly owing to better buying, with Food gross margin down 25 bps compared to our stable estimate, due to price
cuts and higher waste. Opex was +2.2% yoy versus our +3% forecast. Net debt at the end of March was £2.2bn compared to our £2.4bn forecast.

BE

Raising GM gross margin guidance for the year. M&S is now aiming to improve its General Merchandise gross margin by 200-250bps in FY16 compared to
our +210bps estimate. We see a significant gross margin opportunity for M&S driven by increased direct design, increased direct sourcing and lower markdown.
In clothing we think M&S is gaining confidence particularly in terms of buying decisions, however it still lacks a comprehensive merchandise planning system to
improve availability which we expect it to roll out next year. M&S also has an online execution opportunity in its Q3 this year owing to execution issues around
Black Friday last year, which we think it is better set up for this year.
Food margin guidance maintained. M&S has maintained its guidance for its Food gross margin to be stable to up slightly for the full year which we think
incorporates some planned price cuts on key value items. M&S’ food offer is an events-driven business and so less exposed to heavy price deflation on the
regular grocery shop. It has a strong innovation pipeline and we think recent innovation eg the company’s “Taste of…” ranges have been selling well.
Guidance on opex for FY16 has been maintained at +4% versus our +3% forecast given the higher seasonal weighting of H2 but we think this should prove
conservative given recent volume trends and this provides a strong underpin to full year numbers. For FY17 we expect +4% growth due to the introduction of the
living wage from April next year.
Our view: Top Pick, 700p Target Price. We expect to see upside risk to gross margin estimates, which should offset the impact of muted LFL trends. M&S
is outperforming in Food and strong cash generation provides scope for additional cash returns. M&S trades at c.13x cal. 16 P/E, a 15% discount to the UK
General Retail sector and offer a 3.6% dividend yield.
In our September 1 report we set out a 10 point checklist as to how we think M&S can drive a higher valuation over time. M&S has continued to lose share in
clothing and international has proven very challenging, however M&S appears to be delivering strong buying gains and is improving its online execution, with a
big opportunity still to come in Q3, its food business is still outperforming, and it is generating strong cashflow which should enable multi-year cash returns.

PM

i see Freddie George is still a seller

11:36 am
PM

Cantor

PM

Marks & Spencer (SELL) – Interim results gross margins on GM up significantly +285bps but LFLs remain disappointing
MKS LN (521p, TP 490p), Market Cap: £8,544m
Our View: Interim results as with previous updates came in at the top end of market expectations helped by a more significant increase in GM gross margins but in line with our expectations. Adjusted pre-tax profits, before non-underlying charges including £68m of un-flagged restructuring costs, in the six months to September 26th increased by 6.1% to £284m vs. CFE Research £285m (Bloomberg consensus: £271m) on sales up by 1.4% to £5.0bn. UK General Merchandise gross margins rose by 285bps vs. CFE Research +180bps while LFLs were still negative at -1.2% (Q2: -1.9%) vs. CFE Research 0.0%. Food gross margin declined by 25bps vs. CFE Research +20bps while LFLs were +0.2% vs. CFE Research +0.4%. UK operating profits increased by 14.6% to £306.2m vs. CFE Research £281m and International operating profits declined by 50% to £24.7m vs. CFE Research £54m. The Bank contribution came in at £33.6m before adjustments vs. CFE Research £32m. Net debt was £2,200m broadly in line with our expectations. The company confirms it has bought back 11.6m shares for £59.5m (FY2015/2016 share buyback plan: £150m) at an average price of c.512p while the dividend was increased by 6.3% to 6.8p vs. CFE Research 6.8p. The only change to guidance for the current year is that the company now expects GM gross margins to be up by between 200 to 25bps, previously 150 and 200bps.

PM

Following this update, we are maintaining our FY2016 pre-tax profit forecasts of £720m (EPS: 35.24p) vs. Company consensus £703m. We are also retaining our SELL recommendation and our TP of 490p.
· There are likely to be question marks over the quality of the product medium term following unprecedented increases in GM gross margins.

· It is not a given that there will be a recovery in General merchandise sales, which are into their fifth year of negative LFLs.

· Since 2008, M&S’s UK track record has been at best under whelming. UK pre-tax profits have declined by a third, International profits have been flat, the dividend has been reduced and net debt remains above £2bn.

· The initiatives to improve the supply chain and IT infrastructure will not, we believe, lead to a significant increase in sales or profits over the medium term.

· In the meantime, the stock, has broadly tracked the market over the last six months, and is rated at 14.8x on our FY2016 forecast earnings, which broadly puts the stock on a sector rating.

11:37 am
BE

Should also note that Morgan Stanley's Geoff Ruddell, who's a formidable scribbler in spite of being house broker, leaves forecasts unchanged.

BE

The FY H1 beat, and raised General Merchandise gross margin guidance theoretically leaves us with some scope to increase our full year profit expectations. However, the cautious tone of the outlook statement leaves us of the view that it would be prudent to wait until at least the FYQ3 trading update (on January 7, 2016) before pushing through any forecast changes. We leave our Pre Tax Profit forecast for FY 2015/16 unchanged at £710m.

blimey

BE

Agreement in principle on possible share exchange offer

The Boards of Plethora (AIM: PLE) and Regent Pacific (Hong Kong Stock Code: 0575) jointly announce that they have reached agreement in principle on the key terms of a possible share exchange offer to be made by Regent Pacific for all the issued and to be issued share capital of Plethora not already directly or indirectly owned by Regent Pacific (the "Possible Offer").

Regent Pacific and its concert parties together already hold 29.88 per cent. of Plethora's issued ordinary share capital. Furthermore, James Mellon is the Non-Executive Chairman of Plethora and Non-Executive Co-Chairman of Regent Pacific, and Jamie Gibson is the Chief Executive Officer and an Executive Director of both Plethora and Regent Pacific.

Terms of Possible Offer

Under the terms of the Possible Offer, each Plethora Shareholder (other than Regent Pacific) will receive 15.7076 new Regent Pacific shares for each Plethora share. On the basis of the closing price of a Regent Pacific share of HK$0.095 on 3 November 2015 (being the last business day prior to the publication of this announcement, which has commenced an offer period with respect to Plethora), the Possible Offer represents an indicative value for each Plethora share of 12.5 pence and values the entire issued ordinary share capital of Plethora at approximately £102.9 million and values the fully diluted share capital (excluding the out-of-money outstanding options and warrants) at approximately £122.6 million. The Possible Offer represents an indicative premium of approximately:

· 38.9 per cent. to the last equity offer by Plethora which was priced at 9 pence per Plethora share on 29 August 2014;

· 354.5 per cent. to the closing price per Plethora share of 2.75 pence on 3 November 2015 (being the last business day prior to publication of this announcement); and

· 311.7 per cent. to the 30 day volume-weighted average price of Plethora shares of 3.04 pence for the period from 4 October 2015 to 3 November 2015 (being the last business day prior to the publication of this announcement).

BE
